poem:
Title: "In Exaltation of Silences"

In Halberstadt's old church, a dance
Of resonates in bare bellies and breaths.
Its rhythm rendered not in dance,
But the stuttered heartbeat of centuries' hush,
Cage's chord, whispering still.
No encore begged, yet sought in silence,
In this finitude, fleeting, infinite.
Ah, the restless wait for a note unstruck.
In the wait, we are, we are awake.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘There’s a certain madness to it’ … fans await new chord in John Cage gig with 616 years left to run When Halberstadt’s St Burchardi church opens its doors for a once-in-a-lifetime musical experience on Monday, some of the spectators streaming into the 11th-century building will have booked their tickets years in advance and crossed continents to get there. But don’t expect them to demand an encore. Because if one thing is certain about this". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
